document.docAuthor: Gao, Chuan-Bu, Li, Chun-Lin & Fang, Hong
document.docTitle: Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li & Fang 2019, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li, new species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae) from Yunnan, China, and redescription of M. grandicornis (Fairmaire, 1891)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li, new species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Melolonthinae) from Yunnan, China, and redescription of M. grandicornis (Fairmaire, 1891)

heading.emphasis:
Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
CHINA : Yunnan Province : Yingjiang County : Xima Town
.

Megistophylla octobracchia
sp. nov.
/ Chuan-bu Gao & Chun-lin Li / det. 2018 [typeset, yellow label]”, deposited in SYAU.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of holotype (male) ( Figs. 1, 2 , 5–11 , 19–25 , 33–37 ).
Body length 14.5 mm ; width across humeri 6.9 mm ; body oval-elongate, dorsal surface densely punctate, punctures deep rugopunctate; head, pronotum, elytra and pygidium sparsely covered with long setae; scutellum with tiny setae ( Figs. 1, 2 ).
Colour : Antennae, head, pronotum and elytra brown; scutellum and legs reddish brown.

Head : Antennae with 10 antennomeres, antennal club composed of 5 antennomeres, strongly curved outwards, club 2.5 times longer than antennomeres 1–5 combined ( Fig. 5 ). Clypeus setiferous and punctate, anterior margin bow-shaped, reflexed and emarginate. Frons setiferous and densely punctate, frontoclypeal suture defined. Frontal carina distinctly raised, bent forwards medially. Clypeus 1.16 times width, and 0.91 times length of frons ( Fig. 6 ). Frons between eyes 2.1 times width of eye. Ocular canthus setaceous, length of canthus 0.6 mm .

Abdomen : Lateral sides with long setae; ventrite 2 with dense short setae; sternites 5, 6 with soft setae. Pygidium inverted trapezoid, 1.5 times wider than long; surface densely punctate and pubescent ( Fig. 25 ).
Variability. Paratypes differ in size (body length 14.8–15.7 mm , width across humeri 6.6–6.9 mm ). Antennal club 2.1–2.3 times longer than basal antennomeres.

Diagnosis.
Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species can be distinguished from other
Megistophylla
species by the following combination of characters: antennal club composed of 5 long antennomeres; club curved outwards strongly, 2 times longer than basal antennomeres; dorsum of head, pronotum, elytra and pygidium with long soft setae; lateral margin of pronotum moderately crenulate and setaceous; epipleuron with long soft setae before apex; dorsomedial margin of metatibia with 4¯5 small thorns; parameres with eight branches.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4. Habitus of
Megistophylla
in dorsal (1, 3) and lateral (2, 4) view. 1, 2,
Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species , holotype; 3, 4,
Megistophylla grandicornis (Fairmaire, 1891)
. Scale bar: 5.0 mm for 1–4.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. The specific name
octobracchia
means “eight-branched” referring to the branched parameres in the male genitalia of species that are unique in the genus
Megistophylla
.
Chinese name. 八岐多鳃金龟

Remarks. Up to now,
Megistophylla octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species is the third species of the genus known from mainland China . Xima Town (the type locality of the new species) is located at 24°51'24"N– 25°16'24"N and 97°44'54E–97°63'56E, between 820–2580 m a.s.l. ( Zheng & Li 1997 ). When using the key proposed by
Li et al . (2016)
,
M. octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species will be carried to the couplet 5 without regard to the body length. We modify the key in the following manner to comprise
M. octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species :

5 Dorsal surface of elytra glabrous......................................................................... 6 - Dorsal surface of elytra setaceous..........................................
M. octobracchia Gao & Li
, new species 6 Antennal club curved vertically in apical half....................................
M. grandicornis ( Fairmaire, 1891 )
- Antennal club gradually curved outwardly............................................
M. pentaphylla Arrow, 1925
